text: Oh Julia vez a la suya this clip was
shot last week in Syria by Jeanine
DiGiovanni the journalist who was given
a rare visa to travel to Syria and had
the opportunity to meet and talk with
government officials and the Syrian army
do you need what's the mood among Syrian
officials and the Syrian military men
and women today I think it no one wants
war I think that everyone in Syria
whether they're on the opposition side
or the government side are frightened
they're frightened of what's going to
come next the frightened of their lives
changing I think for ordinary people the
fear is the same as it would be for you
and I how to get your children to school
how will you buy food this coming winter
how do the residents of Damascus the
stronghold for President Bashar al-assad
and had been in kind of a bubble for a
long time how are they finding out
what's going on do they even know what's
going on in the rest of the country of
course a lot of contact on the internet
cell phones but it is state television
um although people do watch the BBC they
do skype there's a lot a lot of Syrians
have multiple nationalities so they have
a lot of contact with their their family
outside of the country but still I think
people are very confused um as in the
beginning of many civil wars there's a
lot of misinformation there's a lot of
propaganda people don't know what to
believe and the feeling I get from
everyone I mean the overall general
feeling is fear no one wants their world
to change and collapsing around them and
suddenly Damascus has become a city
that's almost unrecognizable it's to get
from one end to the other to drive there
is not the same route you would have
taken all of your life even if you grew
up there and you've been there before
which makes your experience so valuable
because
you have a basis for comparison how has
Damascus this ancient city how is it
changed between june and September it's
radically changed there's much more
checkpoints set up Syrians are very
social people they have extended family
networks they like to party they like to
go out they like to sit in restaurants
and smoke nagila people are afraid to go
out now did you get a feeling that
people in Damascus have begun to feel a
sense of inevitability that the regime
will fall or do they still hold out hope
of perhaps crushing the uprising and
things kind of miraculously returning to
how they once were people are very
frightened and I think they're very
frightened of that it is no longer and
evolving war that it is a civil war that
winter's coming that there's homeless
people there's food shortages it's very
expensive they're worried that Damascus
will become the next Aleppo
